Question_1.Context: An experiment was conducted on an asymmetric SS + Li/Li-glass/S + C + Al + SS cell. The discharge voltage was monitored to observe the behavior of the cell during discharge.
Question_1.Question: What was the voltage range during which lithium was plated on the positive electrode?
Question_1.Source: The discharge cycle of the cell showed that S8 was not reduced while the cell voltage varied from 2.51 to 2.36 V, during which lithium was plated on the positive electrode.

Question_2.Context: An XPS study was performed on the positive electrode and lithium-metal reference after the cell was opened inside an argon-filled glove box.
Question_2.Question: What was the purpose of the XPS study conducted on the positive electrode and lithium-metal reference?
Question_2.A: To analyze the composition of the positive electrode
Question_2.B: To observe the lithium plating on the positive electrode
Question_2.C: To measure the voltage of the cell
Question_2.Source: XPS data for the positive electrode and lithium-metal reference provided direct evidence of lithium plated on the positive electrode.

Question_3.Context: In a study by F. Leng et al., the degradation processes in lithium-ion commercial batteries during aging were investigated.
Question_3.Question: What was observed between 600 and 800 cycles in the study by F. Leng et al.?
Question_3.A: Lithium plating on the positive electrode
Question_3.B: Surface spallation of the negative electrode
Question_3.D: Insulating layer formation on the positive electrode
Question_3.Source: Between 600 and 800 cycles, lithium plated in the positive electrode according to F. Leng et al.

Question_4.Context: V. Zinth et al. conducted an in-situ neutron diffraction study of a commercial jelly-roll NMC/graphite battery cell at sub-ambient temperatures.
Question_4.Question: What was not identified during the study by V. Zinth et al.?
Question_4.A: Lithium plating on the positive electrode
Question_4.Source: In the study by V. Zinth et al., lithium plating on the positive electrode was not identified while discharging at sub-ambient temperatures.

Question_5.Context: The discharge voltage of an asymmetric SS + Li/Li-glass/S + C + Al + SS cell was monitored to observe the behavior of the cell during discharge.
Question_5.Question: At what voltage did the sulfur start to be reduced in the cell?
Question_5.Source: Below 2.36 V, the sulfur starts to be reduced in the cell.

Question_6.Context: An XPS study was performed on the positive electrode and lithium-metal reference after the cell was opened inside an argon-filled glove box.
Question_6.Question: What did the XPS data provide direct evidence of?
Question_6.A: Lithium plating on the positive electrode
Question_6.B: Carbon contamination on the positive electrode
Question_6.C: Presence of sulfur in the electrolyte
Question_6.Source: XPS data for the positive electrode and lithium-metal reference provided direct evidence of lithium plated on the positive electrode.

Question_7.A: Lithium plating on the positive electrode
Question_7.C: Surface spallation of the negative electrode
Question_7.D: Insulating layer formation on the positive electrode
Question_7.Source: Between 600 and 800 cycles, lithium plated in the positive electrode according to F. Leng et al.

Question_8.A: Lithium plating on the positive electrode
Question_8.Source: In the study by V. Zinth et al., lithium plating on the positive electrode was not identified while discharging at sub-ambient temperatures.
